channel.title: Structure help
channel.description:
I want to design a stock market game, but I'm not sure how I should structure it.
Should I make a corporation object, then give every corporation a class? These corporations obviously need to shift in value, growth rate, etc, so they need to be saved. But I also need to go about saving each corporations investors.
Should I have [code=java5]List<Corporations> corporations;[/code] and then in each corporation class [code=java5]Map<String, Integer> investors;[/code]
I'm a tad confused, so any help or ideas would be nice. Thanks.

item.title: Structure help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Davidi2:

I would understand based on what he said right after that he meant saving them as objects in his program, considering he said he also needs to “save” the corporations and was referring to creating a corporation class…

He’s going to need the investors data saved somewhere too… I mean, he’s adding it in game is he not?
I interpreted it as he needs to physically save it so it can be loaded again when the program restarts.

[quote=“Eyeownyew, post:8, topic:550902”][quote author=n10si t link=topic=669814.msg4478919#msg4478919 date=1428269789]

I’d probably just use a list for the investors, too. What was the reasoning behind using Map<String, Integer>? I don’t know what the intention was with each of those types

Players name, amount invested

[/quote]
go with List, Corporation::Map<Player, Integer>; your approach sounds good but I wouldn’t recommend using a string for each player name. Probably going to have some other variables you save with each player[/quote]

Could use the long that is used for the friends list and ignore list. Each one is unique based on the name, so that wouldn’t be an issue.

Read full topic

item.title: Structure help
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“n10si t, post:3, topic:550902”][quote author=Eyeownyew link=topic=669814.msg4478904#msg4478904 date=1428263027]
I’d probably just use a list for the investors, too. What was the reasoning behind using Map<String, Integer>? I don’t know what the intention was with each of those types
[/quote]

Players name, amount invested[/quote]
go with List, Corporation::Map<Player, Integer>; your approach sounds good but I wouldn’t recommend using a string for each player name. Probably going to have some other variables you save with each player

Read full topic

item.title: Structure help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Davidi2:

@sk8r - why are you even talking about serializing it, thats completely irrelevant to the question at hand

No it’s not:

n10si t:

Should I make a corporation object, then give every corporation a class? These corporations obviously need to shift in value, growth rate, etc, so they need to be saved. But I also need to go about saving each corporations investors.

Read full topic

item.title: Structure help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

@sk8r - why are you even talking about serializing it, thats completely irrelevant to the question at hand

@op - it depends on how in-depth you are making the game. I know some stock market sims just randomize events to raise/lower stock prices, in which case you may not even need to create objects for corporations if you are just using a list of ticker/value pairs. If you want to do things like track history of stocks, or get more in depth in the game details, then yea you would need to. And you wouldnt have a map of <string, int> for investors, you’d probably have that information at the player level

Read full topic

item.title: Structure help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Make an object for the Corporations:

public class Corporation { private String name; //etc etc... }

Then make some form of a list to hold the objects…

Next you can use GSON/JSON for loading and saving the Corporations.

[code=java] Gson gson = new Gson();

// convert java object to JSON format,
// and returned as JSON formatted string
String json = gson.toJson(countryObj);

try {
//write converted json data to a file named "CountryGSON.json"
FileWriter writer = new FileWriter(“E:\CountryGSON.json”);
writer.write(json);
writer.close();

} catch (IOException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}[/code]
Shamelessly ripped from: http://www.java2blog.com/2013/11/gson-example-read-and-write-json.html
(cause screw writing it again)

And that’s basically it.

It’d be easy to save the investor data into the Corporation object using GSON because of how the toJson method works.
If your object has an array of 200 longs, then GSON will save an array of 200 longs.
If you have a list, then it’ll save all the objects in the list. And so on.

Read full topic
